quizzes.defaultCTA: Regardless of which pathway you choose, we're here to answer questions and help. You may find some of our blog articles helpful.

questions.questionText: Who do you have in your life?

children.text: Which of these describe your family situation?

answers.answerText: Married/partnered with children from current relationship only

forFurtherReference.Title: Parents, Step-Parents And Children, Oh My! Blended Families + Death = A Potential Nightmare

Image.name: 2024.03.22 PFL Parents, Step-Parents and Children Oh My.webp

large.name: large_2024.03.22 PFL Parents, Step-Parents and Children Oh My.webp

small.name: small_2024.03.22 PFL Parents, Step-Parents and Children Oh My.webp

medium.name: medium_2024.03.22 PFL Parents, Step-Parents and Children Oh My.webp

thumbnail.name: thumbnail_2024.03.22 PFL Parents, Step-Parents and Children Oh My.webp

children.text: This week we look at a real-life cautionary tale about what can happen in any blended family when the parents leave decisions about their children’s care and inheritance up to their surviving spouse and the state’s laws.

forFurtherReference.Title: Special Needs Planning: Preserving Government Benefits

children.text: A $25,000 inheritance just cost a disabled person their healthcare, housing assistance, and $50,000+ in annual waiver services. Learn how special needs planning protects government benefits while still providing for your loved one's future—and why DIY approaches fail catastrophically in this specialized area.

forFurtherReference.Title: Til Death Do Us Part? Why Unmarried Couples Must Have An Estate Plan That Works For the People They Love

Image.name: 2025.03.14 PFL Til Death Do Us Part Why Unmarried Couples Must Have An Estate Plan That Works For the People They Love.webp

large.name: large_2025.03.14 PFL Til Death Do Us Part Why Unmarried Couples Must Have An Estate Plan That Works For the People They Love.webp

small.name: small_2025.03.14 PFL Til Death Do Us Part Why Unmarried Couples Must Have An Estate Plan That Works For the People They Love.webp

medium.name: medium_2025.03.14 PFL Til Death Do Us Part Why Unmarried Couples Must Have An Estate Plan That Works For the People They Love.webp

thumbnail.name: thumbnail_2025.03.14 PFL Til Death Do Us Part Why Unmarried Couples Must Have An Estate Plan That Works For the People They Love.webp

children.text: Without marriage's legal protections, unmarried couples face unique estate planning challenges that could leave partners vulnerable and children at risk. Learn how to protect your loved ones and assets with proper planning.

questions.questionText: What do you have in your life?

children.text: Which assets do you own? Include assets that also have a loan or mortgage on them. (Select all that apply)

forFurtherReference.Title: Trusts & Homeowner’s Insurance: What You Need to Know So You Don’t Get a Claim Denied In the Future

Image.name: 2025.01.31 PFL [SMP] Your Trust and Home Insurance- What You Need to Know.webp

large.name: large_2025.01.31 PFL [SMP] Your Trust and Home Insurance- What You Need to Know.webp

small.name: small_2025.01.31 PFL [SMP] Your Trust and Home Insurance- What You Need to Know.webp

medium.name: medium_2025.01.31 PFL [SMP] Your Trust and Home Insurance- What You Need to Know.webp

thumbnail.name: thumbnail_2025.01.31 PFL [SMP] Your Trust and Home Insurance- What You Need to Know.webp

children.text: Putting your home in a trust is a smart estate planning move, but it can create unexpected insurance complications if not handled correctly. Learn how to protect one of your most valuable assets by properly aligning your homeowner's insurance with your trust.

forFurtherReference.Title: Real Estate and Estate Planning: Why Your Property Needs More Than Just a Will

children.text: From beneficiary deeds to Master LLCs, explore the tools that keep your properties out of probate court. Essential reading for anyone who owns real estate and wants to avoid leaving their family a legal mess.

forFurtherReference.Title: Protecting Your Family's Safety Net: How to Set Up Your Life Insurance Policy The Right Way

Image.name: 2024.01.19 PFL Protecting Your Family's Safety Net.webp

large.name: large_2024.01.19 PFL Protecting Your Family's Safety Net.webp

small.name: small_2024.01.19 PFL Protecting Your Family's Safety Net.webp

medium.name: medium_2024.01.19 PFL Protecting Your Family's Safety Net.webp

thumbnail.name: thumbnail_2024.01.19 PFL Protecting Your Family's Safety Net.webp

children.text: Life insurance is an important part of protecting your family, but if you don’t set it up the right way, there’s a good chance it won’t help your loved ones the way you want it to. Here’s what to do instead…

forFurtherReference.Title: Business Succession Planning: When DIY Isn't Enough

children.text: You built your business through DIY determination, but succession planning is where that same spirit can destroy what you've created. Learn why business succession requires a different approach and when to stop handling it yourself.

forFurtherReference.Title: The Single Person's Guide to Not Leaving a Digital (and Actual) Mess Behind

children.text: Think estate planning is just for families with kids? That's like saying you don't need cloud backup because you only have one device. The logic doesn't compute. Discover why single people actually need estate planning more—and whether freewill.com can handle your unique situation.
What is your approximate total estate value? Don't subtract for loans here. (All assets combined)
How would you rate the potential for disagreement among your family/beneficiaries about your wishes?

answers.answerText: Very unlikely - everyone gets along well
Somewhat unlikely - minor tensions but generally cooperative
Likely - there are significant relationship challenges
Very likely - active conflicts already exist

children.text: How comfortable are you making decisions about what kind of medical care you'd want if you couldn't speak for yourself? This includes things like life support, feeding tubes, and who should make healthcare decisions on your behalf.

answers.answerText: Very comfortable - I know exactly what I want
Somewhat comfortable - I have a general idea
Neutral - I haven't given it much thought
Somewhat uncomfortable - I have questions about my options
Very uncomfortable - I need help understanding my choices

children.text: Which of these common issues worry you about what would happen after your death? (Select all that apply)

answers.answerText: I want everything to transfer as simply as possible
I want to avoid probate for most/all of my assets
I need to set up specific conditions for inheritances
I want to provide for minor children or dependents

forFurtherReference.Title: Protect Your Children’s Inheritance With A Lifetime Asset Protection Trust

Image.name: 2022.04.01 PFL [SMP] PROTECT YOUR CHILDREN’S INHERITANCE WITH A LIFETIME ASSET PROTECTION TRUST.webp

small.name: small_2022.04.01 PFL [SMP] PROTECT YOUR CHILDREN’S INHERITANCE WITH A LIFETIME ASSET PROTECTION TRUST.webp

medium.name: medium_2022.04.01 PFL [SMP] PROTECT YOUR CHILDREN’S INHERITANCE WITH A LIFETIME ASSET PROTECTION TRUST.webp

thumbnail.name: thumbnail_2022.04.01 PFL [SMP] PROTECT YOUR CHILDREN’S INHERITANCE WITH A LIFETIME ASSET PROTECTION TRUST.webp

children.text: Worried your children’s inheritance could be lost to divorce, debt, or a costly mistake? A Lifetime Asset Protection Trust offers a powerful solution. This unique trust not only shields your kids’ inheritance from life’s unexpected challenges—like lawsuits or bankruptcy—but also empowers them to manage and grow their legacy with confidence. Discover how this trust can provide airtight protection and a lifetime of financial guidance, even for modest estates. Read on to learn how to safeguard your family’s future today!

answers.answerText: I have concerns about beneficiaries' ability to manage their inheritance

forFurtherReference.Title: Protect Your Children’s Inheritance With A Lifetime Asset Protection Trust

children.text: Worried your children’s inheritance could be lost to divorce, debt, or a costly mistake? A Lifetime Asset Protection Trust offers a powerful solution. This unique trust not only shields your kids’ inheritance from life’s unexpected challenges—like lawsuits or bankruptcy—but also empowers them to manage and grow their legacy with confidence. Discover how this trust can provide airtight protection and a lifetime of financial guidance, even for modest estates. Read on to learn how to safeguard your family’s future today!

answers.answerText: I want to include charitable giving in my plan

children.text: Which of the following people are you considering as potential fiduciaries to manage your estate or trust? (Select all that apply)
How would you rate your likelihood of completing all necessary paperwork and tasks on your own? And be honest. Do you typically finish things you start?

answers.answerText: Very high - I'm disciplined and complete what I start
High - I usually finish important projects
Low - I often struggle with follow-through
Very low - I rarely complete complex paperwork

children.text: How do you feel about handling legal documents and processes? Can you deal with lots of moving parts on your own, or do you need instructions clearly communicated to you?

answers.answerText: Very comfortable - I regularly handle complex matters
Somewhat comfortable - I can manage with good instructions
Somewhat uncomfortable - I prefer guidance with legal matters
Very uncomfortable - Legal jargon confuses me

children.text: How important is privacy regarding your estate details?

answers.answerText: Critical - I have specific privacy concerns

children.text: Take this 5-minute assessment to discover which estate planning approach best fits your situation: DIY, guided self-help, or professional planning.
Answer honestly - there are no "right" answers, just the right path for your unique situation.

quizzes.title: Is DIY Estate Planning Right for You?

children.text: Based on your responses, a DIY approach may work well for your situation. You have a relatively straightforward family structure, modest complexity factors, and trusted people available to help with implementation.

Consider using high-quality self-help resources and ensure you properly execute and fund any documents you create. Even with DIY planning, we recommend having healthcare directives reviewed by someone familiar with your state's requirements.

Based on your responses, you would benefit from a guided self-help approach. While you have the capability to handle many aspects independently, your situation has complexity factors that warrant professional guidance at key points.
Consider preparing initial documents yourself, then scheduling a review session with an estate planning attorney to ensure everything is properly structured and executed.

Based on your responses, professional estate planning is recommended for your situation. The complexity factors in your family structure, assets, timeline, or preferences indicate you would benefit significantly from personalized legal guidance.
Professional planning will help ensure your unique circumstances are properly addressed and can provide peace of mind that your wishes will be effectively implemented.
